title: How to Make Beet Hummus

steps.headline: Cook your beets in water.
steps.description:
First trim off the tops. Then clean the roots under running water to remove any dirt. Next, cook them in water in either one of two ways:
In the oven: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (191 degrees Celsius). Place the beats in an oven-safe dish. Add about ¼-inch of water. Place the dish in the oven and bake for 35 minutes or until the beets are tender enough for a knife or fork to puncture them without any effort. On the stovetop: Place the beets in a saucepan. Cover them with water. Bring the water to a boil and then lower to simmer. Cook for 30 minutes or until they are soft enough for your fork or knife to poke through them with zero effort.

steps.headline: Prep your garlic and beets.
steps.description: Transfer the beets to a strainer in the sink or a dry bowl in the fridge. Let them sit until they are cool enough to handle with your bare hands. While they cool, chop your garlic. Once the beets have cooled off, peel off the skins and cut them into small cubes. The size of the cubes doesn’t really matter, but the smaller the cube, the faster it generally takes to blend them.

steps.headline: Blend your ingredients.
steps.description: Add the beets and garlic to a blender or food processor. Then add the tahini paste, lemon juice, ground cumin, lemon zest, salt, and pepper. Pulse them until they combine into a creamy smooth texture. Take a taste test and add more seasonings if desired.

steps.headline: Enjoy or store your hummus.
steps.description: Once it’s made, dig right in if you can't wait and use it as a dip for pita bread, crackers, or vegetables. Otherwise, store in an airtight container, refrigerate, and use within the next three days. If you don’t expect to use it all in that time, store it in the freezer instead.

steps.headline: Roast your beet.
steps.description: First, set your oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (191 degrees Celsius). While it preheats, cut off your beet’s stem plus the majority of the root and then clean them under running water. Then drizzle some canola oil over it and wrap it securely in aluminum foil. Set it on a baking tray and roast for about an hour, or until it’s tender enough to easily pierce with a fork or knife.

steps.headline: Prep your other ingredients.
steps.description: After it’s done roasting, place your beet in the fridge to cool it off. While it chills, drain your can of chickpeas in the sink. Zest your lemon. Mince your garlic. Measure out your other ingredients so everything’s good to go.

steps.headline: Blend your beet.
steps.description: Once it cools off enough to handle without burning yourself, peel the skins. Chop into quarters, then transfer the quarters to a blender or food processor. Pulse until it’s mostly smooth.

steps.headline: Add and blend the rest of your ingredients.
steps.description: Place all ingredients into the blender, except for the olive oil. This includes your chickpeas, lemon zest, lemon juice, salt, pepper, garlic, and tahini. Pulse until the mixture turns as smooth as possible. Then slowly pour the olive oil in while keeping the blender running until it mixes evenly.

steps.headline: Test the flavor and texture, then enjoy.
steps.description: Take a taste test. If desired, add more seasonings. If the texture is thicker than you’d like, blend in a small amount of water and test again. Once it’s right, enjoy right away or store in an airtight container in the fridge. Use within the next seven days.

methods.name: Trying Variations, Toppings, and Serving Suggestions

steps.headline: Turn your hummus golden.
steps.description: Maybe you’re convinced that someone with a bias against beets would really love them if they had no idea they were eating it. Or maybe you just want to switch up its color for the sake of it. Either way, if you want to avoid regular beets’ distinctive color, use golden beets instead for a warmer hue.

steps.headline: Blend beets with pre-made hummus.
steps.description: If you have a container of plain hummus in the fridge but don’t feel too excited about it, or just want fewer dishes to wash afterward, use that as your base. Roast a beet or cook it in water as you would when making hummus for scratch. Then chop it up, toss it in the blender, and add 8 ounces of the plain hummus. Blend it up and enjoy your spruced up hummus.

steps.headline: Top it with basil pesto.
steps.description: Wash your blender or food processor after you make your hummus, or use a second one if you have two. Place all your ingredients inside: fresh basil, olive oil, pine nuts, garlic, salt, and pepper. Pulse until they mix evenly, pausing every so often to push any bits that are crawling up the sides back down with a spoon or spatula. Then spoon it on top of your hummus before serving.

steps.headline: Make an open-faced avocado sandwich.
steps.description: Toast some sandwich bread. Spread the hummus over one side of each slice. Layer some greens like spinach or arugula on top of that. Then top it off with some slices of avocado and sprinkle some crumbled goat cheese over it, and enjoy.

steps.headline: Serve as a dip for snacks.
steps.description: Enjoy your hummus with soft pita bread, pita chips, or crackers. Or, cram even more vegetables into your diet. Serve with sliced carrots, celery, or cucumber for dipping instead.

text:
Plain Beet Hummus Cook your beets in water. First trim off the tops. Then clean the roots under running water to remove any dirt. Next, cook them in water in either one of two ways:
In the oven: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (191 degrees Celsius). Place the beats in an oven-safe dish. Add about ¼-inch of water. Place the dish in the oven and bake for 35 minutes or until the beets are tender enough for a knife or fork to puncture them without any effort. On the stovetop: Place the beets in a saucepan. Cover them with water. Bring the water to a boil and then lower to simmer. Cook for 30 minutes or until they are soft enough for your fork or knife to poke through them with zero effort. Prep your garlic and beets. Transfer the beets to a strainer in the sink or a dry bowl in the fridge. Let them sit until they are cool enough to handle with your bare hands. While they cool, chop your garlic. Once the beets have cooled off, peel off the skins and cut them into small cubes. The size of the cubes doesn’t really matter, but the smaller the cube, the faster it generally takes to blend them. Blend your ingredients. Add the beets and garlic to a blender or food processor. Then add the tahini paste, lemon juice, ground cumin, lemon zest, salt, and pepper. Pulse them until they combine into a creamy smooth texture. Take a taste test and add more seasonings if desired. Enjoy or store your hummus. Once it’s made, dig right in if you can't wait and use it as a dip for pita bread, crackers, or vegetables. Otherwise, store in an airtight container, refrigerate, and use within the next three days. If you don’t expect to use it all in that time, store it in the freezer instead. Roasted Beet Hummus with Chickpeas Roast your beet. First, set your oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (191 degrees Celsius). While it preheats, cut off your beet’s stem plus the majority of the root and then clean them under running water. Then drizzle some canola oil over it and wrap it securely in aluminum foil. Set it on a baking tray and roast for about an hour, or until it’s tender enough to easily pierce with a fork or knife. Prep your other ingredients. After it’s done roasting, place your beet in the fridge to cool it off. While it chills, drain your can of chickpeas in the sink. Zest your lemon. Mince your garlic. Measure out your other ingredients so everything’s good to go. Blend your beet. Once it cools off enough to handle without burning yourself, peel the skins. Chop into quarters, then transfer the quarters to a blender or food processor. Pulse until it’s mostly smooth. Add and blend the rest of your ingredients. Place all ingredients into the blender, except for the olive oil. This includes your chickpeas, lemon zest, lemon juice, salt, pepper, garlic, and tahini. Pulse until the mixture turns as smooth as possible. Then slowly pour the olive oil in while keeping the blender running until it mixes evenly. Test the flavor and texture, then enjoy. Take a taste test. If desired, add more seasonings. If the texture is thicker than you’d like, blend in a small amount of water and test again. Once it’s right, enjoy right away or store in an airtight container in the fridge. Use within the next seven days. Trying Variations, Toppings, and Serving Suggestions Turn your hummus golden. Maybe you’re convinced that someone with a bias against beets would really love them if they had no idea they were eating it. Or maybe you just want to switch up its color for the sake of it. Either way, if you want to avoid regular beets’ distinctive color, use golden beets instead for a warmer hue. Blend beets with pre-made hummus. If you have a container of plain hummus in the fridge but don’t feel too excited about it, or just want fewer dishes to wash afterward, use that as your base. Roast a beet or cook it in water as you would when making hummus for scratch. Then chop it up, toss it in the blender, and add 8 ounces of the plain hummus. Blend it up and enjoy your spruced up hummus. Top it with basil pesto. Wash your blender or food processor after you make your hummus, or use a second one if you have two. Place all your ingredients inside: fresh basil, olive oil, pine nuts, garlic, salt, and pepper. Pulse until they mix evenly, pausing every so often to push any bits that are crawling up the sides back down with a spoon or spatula. Then spoon it on top of your hummus before serving. Make an open-faced avocado sandwich. Toast some sandwich bread. Spread the hummus over one side of each slice. Layer some greens like spinach or arugula on top of that. Then top it off with some slices of avocado and sprinkle some crumbled goat cheese over it, and enjoy. Serve as a dip for snacks. Enjoy your hummus with soft pita bread, pita chips, or crackers. Or, cram even more vegetables into your diet. Serve with sliced carrots, celery, or cucumber for dipping instead.
